headline: Did President Trump's tweet confirm obstruction probe?
subHeadline: This is a rush transcript from "The Fox News Specialists," June 16, 2017.

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, THE FOX NEWS SPECIALIST HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Kat Timpf along with Eric Bolling and Eboni K. Williams. We are The Fox News Specialists. Well, it's been a new twist after new twist today in the soap opera known as the Russian investigation. President Trump delivering a stunning tweet earlier writing, quote, I am being investigated for firing the FBI director by the man who told me to fire the FBI director. Witch hunt. Sources tell Fox News the tweet is in reference to deputy attorney general Rod Rosenstein's overseeing the Russian investigation. Also, a source close to Trump's legal team tells Fox that President Trump was, of course, not confirming in that tweet that he was under investigation for possible obstruction. Instead they say he was just referencing the Washington Post report that claims an obstruction probe is underway. And that's just the tip of the iceberg today. All right, Eric, I know the legal team said he's not confirming, but what else could I am under investigation possibly mean?

utterances.speaker: ERIC BOLLING, THE FOX NEWS SPECIALIST HEAD
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, I don't know. First -- all day long, people are expecting what they're talking about. Rosenstein, are they talking about Mueller? Who are they really talking about? But I guess Fox's asked the team, they said Rosenstein. But think about this, Rod Rosenstein did recommend that they did fire Mueller. So Rod Rosenstein is the guy who -- I'm sorry, fire Comey, but Rod Rosenstein is the guy who hired Mueller. So now we're hearing -- get ready for this, Rod Rosenstein might recuse himself because he feels like he may be too involved in the Russia story, so that would bring on -- let me see, Rachel Brand, who is the associate attorney general. Now she's the third in line at the DOJ. So, I mean, it's getting crazy. Let me just leave you with this thought. The stock market, the Dow made a brand new high, all-time record high to close that high, 21,384 or 5 or so, and record of unemployment, 4.3 percent, it's not been this low since 2001, 16 years ago. Meanwhile, this special counsel, Mueller said he hired 13 new lawyers -- this is today or yesterday, 13 new lawyers. utterances.speaker: TIMPF

utterances.speaker: TIMPF

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

Department of Justice, FBI, and the State Department, and what I'm seeing some six months into this presidency is those have not been rehabilitated whatsoever. In fact, I didn't think it could get worse, I think it's worse. I think those departments are in a worst state credibility wise when they were back in November.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I agree with that. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE

utterances.speaker: TIMPF

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: On another point that you made, Eric, I just want to say just because no evidence has been found yet does not mean it's doesn't exist. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE

utterances.sentences: Jess, we're 11 months into this investigation. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Up next, President Trump announcing a major crackdown on President Obama Cuba policy. Is the era -- with the communist state over? We're coming right back.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: President Trump up ending one of President Obama's most controversial foreign policy decisions, reopening diplomatic and economic ties with Cuba. The two year old policy has long been under fire as a big giveaway to the brutal Castro regime, and President Trump announced a major rollback this afternoon in Miami. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: It's hard to think of a policy that makes less sense than the prior administration's terrible and misguided deal with the Castro regime. Now we hold the cards. We now hold the cards. The previous administration easing of restrictions on travel and trade does not help the Cuban people. They only enrich the Cuban regime. Therefore, effective immediately, I am canceling the last administration's completely one sided deal with Cuba.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: All right, we'll bring it around, Erin, so our audience is clear. This is not a complete rollback of Obama policies. Americans will still be able to travel to Cuba, but we can't do business with the Cuban government and the military. We can do business with the Cuban people, but not anything that -- if you know Cuban policy, almost everything is intertwined with the government and the military.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: Right. So it seems to me that the Trump administration wants to have this both ways. If he actually wanted to keep his campaign promise, it would've been a complete rollback, and it wasn't quite that. So, you know, he said that he's doing this on the ground of human rights, but he's kind of walked both lines on that too, obviously, because in the Trump administration dealing with Saudi Arabia and others, you've had Rex Tillerson, the secretary of state, say that's our value but it's not our policies. So he's.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Right. Eboni, one of the points of this new Trump-Cuban policy is that he has to return our American prisoners. So basically what he's done is he's kept the things -- the economic parts of this alive, at least. It's still alive. So you can still get on a plane and go to Cuba, tomorrow, if you want to. But what he's also has done, he said, you know what, Cuba if you want diplomatic relations with us, you need to sit back down at the table and we'll talk about returning those American prisoners, and we'll talk about your human rights violations. I think it captures both the good -- and of Obama's and the good of Trump's ideas.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So here's my only concern, Eric. I'm actually all about President Trump's ability to negotiate a better deal for the sake of America. It makes perfect sense to me. It's one of the things I'm looking forward to in his administration. My question though becomes, to Erin's point, why we're starting with Cuba when we know about all of the severe human rights violation to Saudi Arabia, we've heard about Russia, we can talk about many people we do business with every day. So I'm just curious, there's a real. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: We're starting there because as Erin points out accurately it was a campaign promise. And I think you're right, Erin, he does gets it both ways is that he get to address the campaign promise of rolling back Obama's Cuba policy.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I think that's why.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Hold on guys, before you go crazy hating on Trump.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Eric, that's not fair. That's not fair to say I'm going crazy beating on Trump. What did I just say just now? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: This is a very good economic feel for the United States. This is a better economic deal for the United States than Obama's economic deal for the United States with Cuba.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: OK. The thing is, though, as both of you pointed out, getting our prisoners back, good thing. That's obviously a good thing. It's obviously a great thing to want to work out a better deal that's better for us. However, as you both pointed out, it doesn't mean that I'm crazy and hating on Trump to point out that, oh, I have a question about why all of a sudden were concerned about human rights violations when were not concerned about it with Saudi Arabia.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Do you like the Cuba -- the Trump-Cuba policy?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It's a very important question because the only difference is Obama like one and not the other. You can flip and say the same thing about Obama.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: No, no, no. This gives us leverage. We have the American consumer, a powerful leverage tool to say, hey, Cuba, you want this consumers to come over there? Here's what we're going to do business with you. The government is not going to take 80 percent of the deal anymore, like they were before. We'll do deals with you with your people, not your government.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I accept that and I understand that. That explanation makes more sense to me. I'm just saying this human rights angle doesn't really make much sense. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: But we are. And I'll bring Jessica, but we are solving part of the human rights problem, part of it. Not all of it, but part of it.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Yes. Any American life that comes home that's been held captive somewhere else is a wonderful day. And any economic gains that we would see is also a wonderful thing. I would say though that from early estimates that we know of as of today, we're actually going to lose 12,000 jobs and it could cost us over $6 billion just doing what he has done so far. utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Can we lift the vengefulness. Can we lift the partisan politics out of it?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I'd love if Donald Trump could.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE

utterances.speaker: BOLLING

utterances.speaker: TARLOV

utterances.speaker: BOLLING

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: How about that this is a better human rights violation -- for human rights to Cuba. It's better for business here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Rollback Obama.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE

utterances.speaker: BOLLING

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The Trump administration making waves over the fate of two Obama-era executive orders on immigration. Now, as the presidential candidate, Trump, was one of the fiercest critics, and last night the administration officially revoked the so-called DAPA program, design to protect the undocumented immigrant parents of U.S. citizens from deportation. Also last night, the administration issued a memo indication that the DACA program, which allows undocumented immigrants brought into the U.S. as children will remain in effect. However, the White House coming out strongly today to say that no final decision has been made on the long-term fate of the program. All right. So, Eric, there are those that were very quick to jump on this, particularly the New York Times came out with a headline right away saying that basically this is Trump not needing a campaign promise. To roll that back, saying that he hasn't met it so far, but these long terms fate unclear. Even if he lets the children stay, the DREAMers, the so-called dreamers stay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right, DACA not DAPA. Is this going to be upset about that geo-state?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: No, I think this is another example of what we've talked about in the last block, the Cuban policy where it's not exactly, hard-core, what he promised in his campaign, but it is -- partially. So it's almost like a negotiation with the illegal community which -- look, that's what -- for me, that's what Donald Trump is all about. Yes, he got -- he went out there and, you know, said a lot of things and he's negotiated better deals, I think, all the way around. I don't think that anyone in in the right mind -- well, I shouldn't say that. I think what -- this is the nicest way to implement what -- that campaign promise he --

utterances.speaker: EBONI WILLIAMS, FBN HOST
utterances.sentences: The spirit of what he wanted. Yes, because I remember Greg Gutfeld --

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: The children get to stay for now, and the illegal parents got to go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Got to go. Because Greg Gutfeld, with someone up here at Fox News that said that most of what Trump said on the campaign trail was an opening negotiation. Is that something you would agree with?

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, FBN HOST
utterances.sentences: So far, from what you've seen.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Well, I think he would tell you that. I think he's talking about the art of the deal, that that's his skill and that seems to be what he's done. Personally, I think that we just need -- and this would go against what Trump would say, but I think we need to open up legal immigration avenues so we double or triple our legal immigration to three million people a year rather than the one million a year.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Oh yes, I agree with that completely.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's important. I mean, that's a great economic boost. Erin, what do you think in terms of how this will play out politically for President Trump?

utterances.speaker: ERIN MCPIKE, LEAD COVERAGE CORRESPONDENT, INDEPENDENT JOURNAL REVIEW
utterances.sentences: Well, I think you're going to see some big, resistant protests after this one because he's cutting it both ways. You know, he did get something on the board for the base, which obviously, the Trump administration is trying to get some wins on the board so that they can engage the base, make it happy. But then I noticed today that the White House rushed to say, "Well, we're not going to make a decision on DACA just yet. They're just stalling that one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So ultimately, do you think they're going to permit the DREAMers to stay?

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: I think so. I think it's a stalling maneuver to cut -- again, throw another old bone to the base. Say, you know, "Hold up, we'll see."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jessica, do you think they'll get to stay, ultimately?

utterances.speaker: JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: I do think that they do. I mean, think that inherently, Donald Trump wouldn't mind if all 11 million people who are here illegally have stayed. But he's been in the Republican primary --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, Donald Trump is a New York City guy. I mean, he's a builder. He is a friend of -- I mean, you hear it all the time -- a friend of police officers, and firemen and union workers. And I think that he, in the past few years -- and this is not just from the campaign, but certainly since he started shifting right and kind of went down the birther hole, and all of that, had moved to a place that I don't think is who he was years ago. So I don't think he cares about the 11 million people, but I think that now, he has made these promises and he is very aware of the fact that, for instance, that border wall is not going up anytime soon, right? That's not going to get through in a spending package. What I would say, though --

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Oh, the wall is going up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How do you know, Eric?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Can I just say about these parents, though? You know, the five million. This program only --

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: The wall will go up before this evidence of collusion between the Russians and the Trump administration.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I'll take that bet, $5, you've got. So these five million peoples, the parents though, I mean, to qualify for this program, you have to have no criminal record. And that was something that Donald Trump was really harsh on that we have to get the criminals out. And also, for the next 10 years, we'll lose $230 billion from the American economy by kicking these people out because they do work, and they will impact the --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And put Social Security and a lot of -- they put money into these programs that they don't even get back out.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Right, even -- they don't just take entitlements.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: They just want to be a part of our society and we should allow them to.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And I- and Eric, you agree that legal immigration --

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Yes, legal. Yes, but the problem is these aren't legal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: We make it easier.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK, we've got to run. They're yelling at me, guys. Coming up, Russia's saying that they have killed the leader of ISIS. How would his death impact the escalating threat from the terror group? Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to "The Fox News Specialists." Our specialists today are Erin McPike along with Jessica Tarlov, who is the author of the upcoming book "America in the Age of Trump." Oh, boy. Oh, boy, oh, boy. I'm going to have to read that one. It's lovely. Let's --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Do you hate Donald Trump? Whatever? Do you mean --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Actually, it's very fair.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Hold on, we have some very, very good news to announce. Russia announcing it may have killed Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi, the leader of ISIS, it says. Received information indicating that Baghdadi was present at a meeting of top ISIS commanders in Raqqa, Syria last month. The gathering was hit by Russian airstrikes. But if officially verified, will this impact the onslaught of recent attacks across the globe by ISIS? Now Erin, I'll start with you. I think this is big news. I think demoralizing to ISIS. But you think differently?

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: Well first of all, it has not been confirmed by a number of other anti --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Some experts say that he wasn't in Raqqa -- in that yet.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: Right, so we don't know yet. But I agree that it could be a moral victory for coalition forces for a while, but you have to think about ISIS as a monster. You cut off its head, two grow in its place. Or eight grow in its place. And I'll tell you this, I went to a Pentagon briefing about last month. When they said Raqqa might not be the final battle. If anti-ISIS forces take back Raqqa, that just means the ISIS fighters who are left are going to go find another territory to claim. And you have to think about this leadership in the same way. Even if their leader is killed, another leader will come in its place.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: So Kat, you and I may agree on this that there are places that we just don't need to be fighting a war. This may be one of them. But how about the good news that it wasn't Americans that killed Baghdadi allegedly, it's the Russians?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Russians, yes. Exactly. The less that we have to be doing in these areas, I think it's better. I'm not somebody who goes, "American dominance, let's just be everywhere with all of our troops just to show how dominant we are." I feel like there's better ways we can spend our money than that, just personally. So I think that's something that you and I agree with.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Like on the Russia investigation

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes, like, things at home, so yes. There you go. So -- yes, but then, you know, we have to just wait and see because this guy has been reported dead more than just this one time.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Yes. Eboni -- yes, it's -- and remember back when we first found out that Al-Baghdadi was the leader of ISIS. And he was up there and -- do you remember that? He was wearing, like, this big Rolex watch.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. Pimping.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: This is the guy -- I think this is the one when you take the lynch pin -- the kingpin down, sometimes -- Erin's right, though. You're not going to kill ISIS, you're just going to turn the name into something else.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Well, think about all of the lone wolves who have been inspired by ISIS. They're not going to go away, either.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. No, look, I mean, is this better than the alternative? Him still being out and about? Absolutely. But no, Eric, I can't say that this makes me feel particularly hopeful that the end of ISIS is near. Certainly, the ideology is so pervasive, unfortunately, and it's so spread out. Frankly, Raqqa -- I mean, I think a lot of people have already moved away from the area and we know that. So I think that, really, what we need to do is attack ISIS on a multi-front type of thing and just get a whole bunch of people at one time. I think these one-offs -- one at a time doesn't really make feel

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Interesting. A little bit of a hawk there, it sounds like.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A little bit, yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Dr. Tarlov, let me ask you?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I'm about to surprise you.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: You are?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I'm excited.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: You're happy about this?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Oh, if it's true? I'm hugely happy about it for the moral victory front and also because I think that it was important. It was so central to Barack Obama's presidency as well that he could have those moments where he could come out and say we've got a big one. And I think that when we are facing the threat of terror attacks, lone wolf attacks here, and people are afraid to go to Europe -- I mean, I'm heading to Europe tonight and I've certainly had conversations with people that were unpleasant to go to France and to England. And there's great concern there, so I think that it is good for morale, for the nation. Not that you shouldn't be afraid anymore, but to say, we are making some advances and we can work with coalition partners that we are still in the midst of sanctioning, but maybe Russia can be useful to us in some way. So I wait on confirmation.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: And we'll leave it on there. That's a great note to leave it on. When we come right back, it's Kat on the street bringing some levity amid some very emotional news this week. Plus, powerful moments of unity at last night's Congressional Baseball Game in the wake of Wednesday's shooting. Stick around.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It's been a rough, emotional news week, to put it mildly. There's plenty of reasons to feel gloomy about things. Yesterday was National Smile Power Day, and on the streets of New York, some people still had some reasons to smile.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: So today is National Smile Day. I don't really like people telling me what to do, so I was like, boo. What do you think about smiling?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Smiling is pretty fun.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I love it. Things make me smile. Food makes me smile.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Just random acts of people in general.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: People in general is why I frown. What kind of stuff do you like to smile about?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Jokes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Like telling some jokes in the sunshine with your family?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, that would do it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: So what else makes you smile?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Bunnies.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: But do you ever think about how, you know, they die?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I love smiling.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You love smiling?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, it makes -- it's beautiful. It makes me look sexy.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It seems like everyone I talked to today really love smiling. What do you guys think?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Smiling is very, I think, infectious.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I think it brings out the best of people.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I feel like frowns don't get the credit that they really deserve. Frowns got a bad rep a little bit.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, they do.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You know, I feel like there's some positives to frowning.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What about my smile. Ready?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's cute. It's like -- and what about this?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: No?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: And I smile like --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I love (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Is that a good one? What about this? No, not a good one?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Like, kind of a stank look, you know what I mean? It's like --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Smiles like this?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Smiles like -- yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Good one?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's a good one.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: He's a liar.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Smile to everybody. Doesn't matter who it is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMLAE
utterances.sentences: I think it's just a powerful tool of communication.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I feel like the right guy, for me, would be, like, more into frowning.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Interesting.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: So you don't think there should be, like, a frown day?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No, no. I feel like the world is such a bitter place right now and it's such a sad place that if everyone just truly smiled at each other a little more, it might make the world just a little better.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I've been told I don't look approachable. Is that true?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How come you don't?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Because I don't want to. I don't always want to. Do you think I should smile a little more?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Only for today.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: All right. See, never, ever smile. You don't know who's falling in love with your frown.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Who edited that package?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Not sure who did.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Monica, probably. Good stuff. Good job, Monica.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Great job, Monica.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Last night, politics and partisanship took a timeout during the annual Congressional Baseball Game in Washington. Lawmakers and tens of thousands of attendees turned out to honor the heroics of the capitol police officers who prevented a massacre and paid tribute to the wounded congressman, Steve Scalise and the other victims of witness -- excuse me, Wednesday's shooting.

utterances.speaker: ED HENRY, FOX NEWS REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Just getting around second base, because remember, Steve Scalise was manning second base on that practice field.

utterances.speaker: MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: You can hear everybody chanting "USA." It's very moving here tonight, I have to say. I mean --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: And they're coming together for a prayer.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And now everybody is kneeling down to pray. Let's take a moment here.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: This is Officer Bailey, who was injured and who took down the shooter with his Officer Greiner, who was also working with him. He threw out the first pitch.

utterances.speaker: PAUL RYAN, HOUSE SPEAKER
utterances.sentences: We spent every day together, working together. Our families are closer, staffs are very close. He's in the hospital. He's recovering. He's got a ways to go. We're all praying for him.

utterances.speaker: NANCY PELOSI, HOUSE MINORITY LEADER
utterances.sentences: We're all close to Steve Scalise, he's a lovely person. But this game is a game where we always come to have run. It's good for everybody. They do their very best and hope that our team wins. Tonight we're all Team Scalise.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: A lot of heartwarming moments last night. Also, doctors provided an update on Congressman Scalise's health today, saying he's still in critical condition, but they've controlled his internal bleeding and his vital signs have stabilized. All great. Really, really --

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Can I point out Officer Bailey -- that was the most heartwarming moment of the whole night. You know, he's the one who returned fire on the psychopath on Wednesday, throwing that pitch out. You just got to say, you know, thank God for men and women like Officer Bailey and the other Capital Hill police officer, female, who was also shot as well. And just one a side note, he threw in a pitch better than Barack Obama did when he threw that pitch.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God. Always.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Oh, just that

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well maybe they're talking

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Well, the liberals did win, though. The liberals did win.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: They did.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: And -- but did you see they brought the trophy immediately to Steve Scalise's office, and that the captain -- that was always his plan, but he didn't tell the team until the end because he wanted them to, you know, remain competitive. But they immediately went straight for it. I thought it was fantastic. It was nice to see Paul Ryan and Nancy Pelosi together.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: That was the most ingenuous moment of the night, when Nancy Pelosi, after spending the day trashing Republicans for the shooting of Republicans, blaming Republicans and Fox, and then she said -- then she has the audacity to go sit next to Paul Ryan and say it's Steve Scalise's tonight.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, she got off her talking points. And quite frankly, I think that's a problem because she's the leadership of the party of -- because I think the party is handicapped, quite frankly, by having her in the role because they can't grow beyond it. I will say I was happy also to see all the LSU gear, like, all that purple and gold, it was a very nice nod to Steve Scalise.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: I was there last night and I would say that it is the most engaged audience I have ever seen at Nats Park. It was a nice night.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: For this game? Because Nats are in the playoffs --

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: Well, not now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Is that Nats shade coming from you?

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: But I like the Nats, but they always disappoint us.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: You know what the good news is? Maybe -- the silver lining to all of us, maybe it brings awareness to this game and the money that they waste.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: Yes. A couple thousand a year.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Yes, so that the years going forward, they raise a lot more money.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They raised a million this year, so that's great.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I think so. Yes, no, I talked to a couple of people yesterday, staffers on the Hill who didn't normally go, and just friends from D.C. and they said we're all going. I think it's just sensational. And we know it's New Yorkers here. You know, what can happen out of times of tragedy and people really coming together and -- you know, besides Nancy Pelosi, that inauthentic witch.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Jessica Tarlov, she literally blamed conservatives in the morning, Fox News in the afternoon, for the shooting you know --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I love it, you for that one.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: -- the attempted murders of, you know, 30 or so Republicans. And then she pretends to be buddy-buddies with Paul Ryan.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: So I don't think that what she said, we're all Team Scalise, that she was pretending there. She's known him for a really long time

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: You don't?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm saying. I think those -- that was her coming off her talking point, the moment but she acknowledged that -- kind of an off comment, but a question, what are your thoughts on Nancy Pelosi being the face of the Democratic Party in this moment?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I actually think that when Tim Ryan, the young Ohio Republican challenged her for the leadership, I thought that that was a healthy thing, to be at least having the conversation about where the party is today and how we're going to win more elections. I mean, we -- obviously, we lost big in 2016, but we lost over a thousand seats during Barack Obama's term. That conversation needs to be had. I do think that she has been and continues to be an effective leader, but I don't know what's going to happen in the coming years. And I think that we certainly need to be, you know, getting an excellent farm team up there, right? And pulling more people in like Tim Ryan and the Mayor from South Bend, Indiana, who is fantastic and was running for DNC chair. There are a lot of young, exciting people, and the enthusiasm, also, on the young Democrats to get out there and start running, especially women, has been huge. Thousands saying that they're going to run. So I think it's -- I think the future is bright.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: How long does the unity last?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It's already kind of not.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, I think there will be shades of it next week. But I don't think it will last much longer.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Like Monday morning-ish?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Once that health care bill drops, I think you will not see any unity anymore.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: Right. Probably not.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So sad.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It's very sad. But it's politics.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, when we return, we will circle back with our specialists Erin McPike and Jessica Tarlov. Don't go away.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Time to circle back with our specialists, Erin McPike and Jessica Tarlov. All right, I will start with you, Erin. I have a question for you about your dog. I need to know the breed, I need to know how long you've had your dog -- since I'm a new doggy mommy -- and I love that your dog is named after Benjamin Franklin.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: Benjamin Franklin, yes. His birthday is July 3rd, one day before Jessica's book comes out. He'll be a year old on July 3rd. He is a purebred black lab, and I've had him since Labor Day weekend last year.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. You get criticisms that your dog has a real person's name, because my dog is named Carrie James and people, like, give me a hard time. Because they feel like it should have a puppy name like Coco or something.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I like that.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: I like having a real name. And people say to me that Franklin's a great name. And I've had people say, oh, he must be the smartest dog in puppy class, because his name is Franklin.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's

utterances.speaker: BOLLINGS
utterances.sentences: My dog's name is Freedom.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Freedom? I like that, Eric.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Your dog's name is Freedom?

utterances.speaker: BOLLINGS
utterances.sentences: Can I point out these two specialists just for one second right now? Erin McPike, one of the most well-respected journalists in D.C., we're thankful to have you. IJR. You work at IJR now. Great group of people. One of my must-reads in the morning.

utterances.speaker: MCPIKE
utterances.sentences: Oh, good.

utterances.speaker: BOLLINGS
utterances.sentences: And Jessica Tarlov, Dr. Jessica Tarlov. I'm not joking. You have a PhD in political science, right?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I do. Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLLINGS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's great stuff.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I have a question for you, though, Jessica.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Is it about my thesis?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So your book --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I promise.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Your book's coming out July 4th.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: How can you do that when you're a Democrat? Which means you don't like America.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Oh, totally. Yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: So tell us about your book.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Yes. I'm really excited. I wrote it with Doug Schoen, who's also a Fox News contributor. And I worked for him for a blissful four and a half years.

utterances.speaker: BOLLINGS
utterances.sentences: Blissful.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No -- what?

utterances.speaker: BOLLINGS
utterances.sentences: That could be the first time anyone talked about working with Doug as being blissful. But OK.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Doug is watching. I didn't say that. Anyway, so actually, it's not a partisan book. It's a --

utterances.speaker: BOLLINGS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No, no. It -- no, legitimately, it's not. It is a road map.

utterances.speaker: BOLLINGS
utterances.sentences: It's Friday. We have 30 seconds left in this show.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Anyway, it's a road map, a bipartisan road map to how we can address about 10 or 11 key issue areas, and leave whole solutions from the left and from right -- center left and the center right, actually -- to show how we can come together on, like, health care, and the economy, and national security. And it's really good. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much to our Fox News specialists today, both Erin McPike and Jessica Tarlov. And thank you all for watching. Make sure you follow us on social media, @specialistfnc on both Twitter and Facebook. And remember, five o'clock will never be the same. "Special Report" up next.
